Jeff,

  I don't think that approach you've describing is actually relevant here.
  Anyway, it does work fine if you set a breakpoint in the code or 
exception breakpoint, then code can be replaced. However I have hard 
time to rerun test cases created by my suite method. You are right that 
with "keep junit running" option in debug mode "Run" action does not 
fail, but it does not execute the test either. I've added tracing to the 
test method and it is just not being called. I still wonder what am I 
doing wrong here?

  I am using Eclipse 3.2M1...

  regards,
  Eugene


Jeff Grigg wrote:

>--- Eugene Kuleshov <eu@m...> wrote:
>  
>
>>   Thank you for cheching this. But exactly this sequence does
>>not work for me and never worked giving the errors like this:
>>
>>junit.framework.AssertionFailedError: Could not create
>>test 'testParam 0.8010281114425616'
>>   at junit.framework.TestResult$1.protect(TestResult.java:106)
>>
>>   Can you please confirm that you actually tried the test
>>suite I've sent? It generates 100 test cases using the
>>following suite() code:
>>[...]
>>    
>>
>
>I found, upon looking into it, that Eclipse does have the /option/ 
>of keeping the JUnit process/JVM running, so it can restart 
>individual test instances.
>
>Eclipse 3.0.1 gives me this informative error message:
>  "To rerun tests they must be launched under the debugger
>   and 'Keep JUnit running' must be set in the launch configuration"
>
>So this only works with DEBUG runs.  And then only if you enable 
>it.  (And it can only be enabled if your JVM supports "hot code 
>replacement.")  This is not the default behavior.
>
>(And *good luck* if you're using NetBeans, JBuilder or ant, and you 
>want process and instance preservation across runs!!!   ;-)
>
>From "help" documentation:
>  'A JUnit launch configuration has a "keep alive" option. If your 
>Java virtual machine supports "hot code replacement" you can fix the 
>code and rerun the test without restarting the full test run. To 
>enable this option select the Keep JUnit running after a test run 
>when debugging checkbox in the JUnit launch configuration.'
>
>...
>
>Otherwise, it launches a new process (new JVM, new test object 
>instances) on each JUnit run.
>
>To see this behavior, select "Window -> Preferences", "Run/Debug -> 
>Launching" and uncheck the "Remove terminated launches when a new 
>launch is created" option.
>
>Then, in the "Debug" view (so you can see the list of processes, run 
>a few tests.  Each one gets its own process.
>
>Now it's true that when my 'suite()' method builds tests from 
>standard TestCase classes with standard test methods, I can rerun 
>any test class or method with a right click, "Run".  But each one 
>spawns a separate process.
>
